question: Have any iGEM teams explored the use of DNA nano-structures for targeted DNA binding and subsequent structural changes, such as G-quadruplex formation, for various applications?
reference_answer: Although the provided context does not mention other iGEM teams, it does describe a project that utilizes DNA nano-structures for targeted DNA binding and G-quadruplex formation, suggesting that at least one team has explored this concept.
qa_context: DNA nano-structure has the ability to bind with targeted DNA strand. When target DNA is bound with the nano- structure, it could facilitate the formation of G-quadruplex in one end. This could lead to peroxidation of the target DNA...Our project is divided into two parts. The first part is to check whether the Lactobacillus DNA fragment could be bound with designed DNA nano-Structure.

qa_meta.Project_Title: NANO-TECHtrahedron: Using nano-tetrahedron to check for the probiotic concentration from food sample
qa_meta.Abstract: In iGEM 2017, our team successfully designed a DNA three dimensional nano-structure to detect the presence and concentration of H3N2 influenza mRNA biomarker. To further prove the ability of the DNA nano-structure, this year we used four DNA strands to form a DNA nano-structure to detect the presence and the concentration of Lactobacillus instead of just a gene fragment of a bacterium. We successfully designed nano- triangular bipyramid applicable to the bacterium using Tiamat. We then successfully detect the presence and concentration of bacteria by measuring its peroxidase activity.

answer: Yes, this context directly states that the iGEM team 'HK SKHLPSS' in the year 2017 and 2019 have used DNA nano-structures for targeted DNA binding. However, in the 2017 project, they used the DNA nano-structure to detect the presence and concentration of H3N2 influenza mRNA biomarker.

qa_meta.Project_Title: How I Met Diphto
qa_meta.Abstract: Diphtheria, a lethal disease caused by the toxigenic strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, afflicted Indonesia in /10 mortality rates upon 593 national cases. Complicated diagnostic method and ambiguous symptoms were the main obstacles in giving the optimal treatment, according to physicians. Therefore, a fast and convenient novel approach to enhance diagnostic precision is needed to mitigate diphtheria immediately. In regards, our team focuses on developing the diagnostic tool using K-12 chimeric bacteria and green fluorescent protein (GFP) to enable a rapid detection of Diphteria toxin upon binding. This novel technology is claimed to be fast, available, and easy-to-usewhich sets stepping stones regarding to the establishment of primary diagnostic tool for Diphtheria toxin worldwide. In addition, we aim to prevent future outbreaks using public education to enhance awareness regarding anti-hoax movements and introduce daily probiotic consumption to encounter low usages of probiotic in Indonesia

answer: Yes, the UI Indonesia team utilized the SDS Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) protocol in their project "How I Met Diphto" as mentioned in their Wiki content. However, only step 1 of setting up the glass plates using Bio-Rad Mini-PROTEAN Tetra Cell kit is explicitly mentioned, along with an incomplete mention of repeating steps 10-14 and combining the elutes in the provided context.

Our members come from different backgrounds, with majors such as chemistry, chemical engineering, biology. However, we have something in common- we all are interested in synthetic biology and admire the concept of iGEM. At first, we were frustrated because of all of the details that need to be carefully accounted for, but after a lot of dedication, we observed that people are suffering HAI(Hospital Acquired Infection) these days. qa_meta.Project_Title: shrimpal.id: Early Detection Tool for White Feces Disease in White Shrimp Ponds
qa_meta.Abstract: Vibrio parahaemolyticus, an emerging pathogen of white shrimp that cause White Feces Disease (WFD), still poses major threat in white shrimp industry. Unfortunately, Vibrio parahaemolyticus is hard to detect; shrimp farmers tries to estimate its existence through physicochemical and traditional parameterswhich does not always give accurate prediction. We design Escherichia coli that could detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in shrimp pond water and estimates its quantity. We try to express the signaling proteins of Vibrio parahaemolyticus in Escherichia coli: LuxN, LuxO, and LuxU and integrate them with dCas9 system that regulates GFP expression. It is expected that when the Vibrio parahaemolyticus level is high, it would produce enough autoinducer molecules to be detected by LuxN and induces the cascade of the system until GFP is expressed. This system would allow shrimp farmers to detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in their ponds earlier and easier, hence they could do preventive measures to stop WFD.

answer:
Based on the provided context, there is one instance of an iGEM team utilizing a bacterial strain, "E. coli" (not explicitly E. coli TOP10), in their project. 

The team, ITB Indonesia, used Escherichia coli (E. coli) to design a system for early detection of White Feces Disease in white shrimp ponds. They expressed the signaling proteins of Vibrio parahaemolyticus in E. coli and integrated them with the dCas9 system that regulates GFP expression. The goal of this system is to allow shrimp farmers to detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in their ponds earlier and take preventive measures to stop White Feces Disease.

qa_meta.Project_Title: Anti-Aphid Angiosperm: use cotton chitinase gene to resist pest invasion
qa_meta.Abstract: Our project uses agrobacteria to produce chitinase in tobacco leaves in order to help resist insect`s infection. Chitin is the composition of insects` exoskeleton and digestion tract. Chitinase can decompose chitin and hence reduce insect infection. This method can be used as a `green pesticide` which doesn`t damage the environment. The agrobacteria can transfer part of its plasmid into plant genome, which is the T-DNA. We inserted the chitinase gene into the vector pCAMBIA 2301 and adopted a binary system. We first let the vector amplify in E.coli DH5. Then, we extracted the plasmids and inserted them into agrobacteria tumefacien GV3101. The bacteria can be injected into tobacco leaves and contribute to a brand new ability to defend against pests.

question: Have any iGEM teams encountered issues with constitutive expression systems in their projects and explored alternative approaches to regulate gene expression?
reference_answer: Yes, at least one team encountered complications with a constitutive expression system, specifically experiencing a large metabolic load on the bacteria, and opted for a light-inducible expression system instead.
qa_context: But when we tested the system, we discovered multiple complications that would render the constitutive expression system virtually unusable/unsuitable. The rapid, unending production of PETase resulted in a large metabolic load on the bacteria and made it more difficult to sustain the population. In the end, it was clear that the light-inducible expression system was the better choice.

qa_meta.Project_Title: Development of PET Degradation Device Using Transgenic Escherichia Coli
qa_meta.Abstract: In the past 65 years (1950 to 2015) only 7% of the 83 billion tons of plastic have been recycled, and 50% has been dumped into the environment. The effort of reducing plastic in the environment is being made by various fields, however due to the high cost of plastic treatment and its harmful side products a breakthrough is yet to be made. In this project we have established an improved PET degradation system. First, we utilized point mutations with enhanced PET degradation, and implemented a light inducible promoter to regulate the expression of PET-degrading enzymes more effectively. To increase the efficiency of the enzyme expression, we determined the best combination of some constitutive promoters and RBS. Not only that, we used a new signal peptideto increase the amount of secreted enzymes. From these results, we constructed a circulating incubator in which PET is degraded by transgenic E.coli.

answer: No information in the given context is available to directly support or refute the idea that iGEM teams encountered issues with constitutive expression systems. However, it's stated that the 'light inducible expression system, which was used by many iGem teams', but the provided context does not reveal any alternative approaches found by other teams. It does however, reveal that team SIS Korea found an alternative in using a light-inducible expression system as the better choice due to complications in the constitutive expression system.

qa_context: Cultivate bacteria on the shaker for 12 to 16 hours 11\.Extract plasmids using plasmid Extraction Kit (provided by TAKARA) 12\.Transform the plasmsids into Agrobacteria tumefacien (GV3101) electroporation competent cells ( provided by Mitose) a.Take out the competent cells from fridge (storage condition: -80) and place it on the ice box for melting; b.Leave it into ice-bath again for 2 minutes; c. minutes at 180rpm to promote cell replication; d. Use the glass rod to distribute bacteria evenly across the medium surface and let it dry; e. Leave the culture dish upside down and cultivate bacteria for 12-16 hours.

qa_meta.Project_Title: Anti-Aphid Angiosperm: use cotton chitinase gene to resist pest invasion
qa_meta.Abstract: Our project uses agrobacteria to produce chitinase in tobacco leaves in order to help resist insect`s infection. Chitin is the composition of insects` exoskeleton and digestion tract. Chitinase can decompose chitin and hence reduce insect infection. This method can be used as a `green pesticide` which doesn`t damage the environment. The agrobacteria can transfer part of its plasmid into plant genome, which is the T-DNA. We inserted the chitinase gene into the vector pCAMBIA 2301 and adopted a binary system. We first let the vector amplify in E.coli DH5. Then, we extracted the plasmids and inserted them into agrobacteria tumefacien GV3101. The bacteria can be injected into tobacco leaves and contribute to a brand new ability to defend against pests.

answer: Yes, at least one team used Agrobacterium tumefaciens as a chassis organism for their project. The team "Nanjing" employed electroporation to transform Agrobacterium tumefaciens GV3101. They first let the vector amplify in E.coli DH5, then extracted the plasmids and inserted them into Agrobacterium tumefaciens GV3101 using electroporation.

qdrant_context.Abstract: In iGEM 2017, our team successfully designed a DNA three dimensional nano-structure to detect the presence and concentration of H3N2 influenza mRNA biomarker. To further prove the ability of the DNA nano-structure, this year we used four DNA strands to form a DNA nano-structure to detect the presence and the concentration of Lactobacillus instead of just a gene fragment of a bacterium. We successfully designed nano- triangular bipyramid applicable to the bacterium using Tiamat. We then successfully detect the presence and concentration of bacteria by measuring its peroxidase activity.

He also instructed us to use various online platforms, such as BLAST, to find out the appropriate sequence of the bacteria as our target sequence.

qdrant_context.Abstract: It is the Tunghai team`s first year to compete in the iGEM competition. Our team consists of 15 students working together in multidisciplinary teams to achieve our goal. Our members come from different backgrounds, with majors such as chemistry, chemical engineering, biology. However, we have something in common- we all are interested in synthetic biology and admire the concept of iGEM. At first, we were frustrated because of all of the details that need to be carefully accounted for, but after a lot of dedication, we observed that people are suffering HAI(Hospital Acquired Infection) these days. It can`t be denied how crucial the whole environment is to this human being. Therefore, we invented a new product and named it `EcoLife`, with its primary purpose being a air purifier. With this product, we are looking to provide a instrument alternative for those who pursue a healthy life.

question: Have any iGEM teams developed or utilized standard curves based on optical density measurements for cell number calculations in their projects?
reference_answer: Although the provided context does not specifically mention an iGEM team, it does describe the use of an OD600 standard curve for cell number calculation, which suggests that the approach is being used in a research or project setting, possibly by an iGEM team or a similar research group.
qa_context: We already made V.parahaemolyticus standard curve to determine cell number based on OD600. This standard curve used to be used to calculate cell number. We are now using the OD600 standard curve for cell number calculation. We will use the OD 600 standard curve in the future.

qa_meta.Project_Title: shrimpal.id: Early Detection Tool for White Feces Disease in White Shrimp Ponds
qa_meta.Abstract: Vibrio parahaemolyticus, an emerging pathogen of white shrimp that cause White Feces Disease (WFD), still poses major threat in white shrimp industry. Unfortunately, Vibrio parahaemolyticus is hard to detect; shrimp farmers tries to estimate its existence through physicochemical and traditional parameterswhich does not always give accurate prediction. We design Escherichia coli that could detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in shrimp pond water and estimates its quantity. We try to express the signaling proteins of Vibrio parahaemolyticus in Escherichia coli: LuxN, LuxO, and LuxU and integrate them with dCas9 system that regulates GFP expression. It is expected that when the Vibrio parahaemolyticus level is high, it would produce enough autoinducer molecules to be detected by LuxN and induces the cascade of the system until GFP is expressed. This system would allow shrimp farmers to detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in their ponds earlier and easier, hence they could do preventive measures to stop WFD.

answer: According to the given context, "We already made V.parahaemolyticus standard curve to determine cell number based on OD600. This standard curve used to be used to calculate cell number. We are now using the OD600 standard curve for cell number calculation." So, yes, at least one iGEM team (ITB Indonesia) has developed and utilized a standard curve based on OD600 (optical density measurements at 600 nm) for cell number calculations in their project.

question: Have any iGEM teams developed or utilized novel methods for culturing or rejuvenating microorganisms, or explored alternative approaches to traditional techniques such as streaking or spread plating?

qa_context: Streak method used for rejuvenating culture, while spread plate used for spread the culture evenly in the agar plate so the single colonies are formed. answer: Yes, multiple iGEM teams utilized gel electrophoresis for the separation and analysis of gene fragments in their projects. Specifically, the UI Indonesia team used a MUPID-exU Horizontal Electrophoresis System, and the ITB Indonesia team and the Tunghai TAPG team used agarose gel electrophoresis for their experiments.

qdrant_context.Abstract: Diphtheria, a lethal disease caused by the toxigenic strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, afflicted Indonesia in /10 mortality rates upon 593 national cases. Complicated diagnostic method and ambiguous symptoms were the main obstacles in giving the optimal treatment, according to physicians. Therefore, a fast and convenient novel approach to enhance diagnostic precision is needed to mitigate diphtheria immediately. In regards, our team focuses on developing the diagnostic tool using K-12 chimeric bacteria and green fluorescent protein (GFP) to enable a rapid detection of Diphteria toxin upon binding. This novel technology is claimed to be fast, available, and easy-to-usewhich sets stepping stones regarding to the establishment of primary diagnostic tool for Diphtheria toxin worldwide. In addition, we aim to prevent future outbreaks using public education to enhance awareness regarding anti-hoax movements and introduce daily probiotic consumption to encounter low usages of probiotic in Indonesia

qa_meta.Project_Title: Plasteriase: Mutating a Bacterial PET-degrading Enzyme
qa_meta.Abstract: Polyethylene terephthalate, PET, formed by condensation and polymerisation of terephthalic acid (TPA) and ethylene glycol (EG), is one of the most commonly used polyesters in the world. The degradation rate of PET is significantly slow which make them extremely persistent and hard to dispose. Although PETase can biologically degrade PET, the rate of enzymatic reaction is not suitable for usage in plastic waste treatment. Therefore, creating mutants which have a higher PET degradation activity may represent an effective and a long term solution of pollution from PET. After structural studies of PETase and its mutants, we hypothesized a more hydrophobic surface and narrower substrate binding site could lead to an increase in activity due to a better substrate interaction with PET. In our study, four single or double PETase mutants are produced and their PET degrading capacity are measured by enzyme activities for para-nitrophenol (pNP)-aliphatic esters.

answer: Yes, team HK GTC worked on optimizing enzyme assays for PETase, specifically using different DMSO concentrations and substrate concentrations. They used 1mM substrate and 45mM Na2HPO4-HCl buffer to attain the highest percentage increase of OD reading for E1, according to the provided context.

qa_meta.Project_Title: shrimpal.id: Early Detection Tool for White Feces Disease in White Shrimp Ponds
qa_meta.Abstract: Vibrio parahaemolyticus, an emerging pathogen of white shrimp that cause White Feces Disease (WFD), still poses major threat in white shrimp industry. Unfortunately, Vibrio parahaemolyticus is hard to detect; shrimp farmers tries to estimate its existence through physicochemical and traditional parameterswhich does not always give accurate prediction. We design Escherichia coli that could detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in shrimp pond water and estimates its quantity. We try to express the signaling proteins of Vibrio parahaemolyticus in Escherichia coli: LuxN, LuxO, and LuxU and integrate them with dCas9 system that regulates GFP expression. It is expected that when the Vibrio parahaemolyticus level is high, it would produce enough autoinducer molecules to be detected by LuxN and induces the cascade of the system until GFP is expressed. This system would allow shrimp farmers to detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in their ponds earlier and easier, hence they could do preventive measures to stop WFD.

qdrant_context.Abstract: Our project uses agrobacteria to produce chitinase in tobacco leaves in order to help resist insect`s infection. Chitin is the composition of insects` exoskeleton and digestion tract. Chitinase can decompose chitin and hence reduce insect infection. This method can be used as a `green pesticide` which doesn`t damage the environment. The agrobacteria can transfer part of its plasmid into plant genome, which is the T-DNA. We inserted the chitinase gene into the vector pCAMBIA 2301 and adopted a binary system. We first let the vector amplify in E.coli DH5. Then, we extracted the plasmids and inserted them into agrobacteria tumefacien GV3101. The bacteria can be injected into tobacco leaves and contribute to a brand new ability to defend against pests.

question: Have any iGEM teams utilized affinity tags, such as histidine tags, for protein purification in their projects?
reference_answer: Yes, at least one iGEM team has used a 6XHis-Tag for protein purification, specifically for the separation of PETase from other cellular proteins using nickel resin and columns.
qa_context: PETase is fused with a C-terminal 6XHis-Tag which is outside of its globular structure where the other cellular proteins do not.Histidine is capable to form dative covalent bond with nickel(II) ion. We used nickel resin and columns to separate the enzyme from other cellular protein in the supernatant.

qa_meta.Project_Title: Plasteriase: Mutating a Bacterial PET-degrading Enzyme
qa_meta.Abstract: Polyethylene terephthalate, PET, formed by condensation and polymerisation of terephthalic acid (TPA) and ethylene glycol (EG), is one of the most commonly used polyesters in the world. The degradation rate of PET is significantly slow which make them extremely persistent and hard to dispose. Although PETase can biologically degrade PET, the rate of enzymatic reaction is not suitable for usage in plastic waste treatment. Therefore, creating mutants which have a higher PET degradation activity may represent an effective and a long term solution of pollution from PET. After structural studies of PETase and its mutants, we hypothesized a more hydrophobic surface and narrower substrate binding site could lead to an increase in activity due to a better substrate interaction with PET. In our study, four single or double PETase mutants are produced and their PET degrading capacity are measured by enzyme activities for para-nitrophenol (pNP)-aliphatic esters.

answer:
A related information is mentioned in the context from the Wiki_content under 'Retrieved Projects Information', that mentions "Application of inteins in building protein affinity purification system", and further mentions 'His 6x which can bind to metal divalent ions, and facilitate the purification of the target protein'.

Also, in the third part of the context from 'Team:Tunghai TAPG/Results' mentions that the proteins added were 'eGFP, SUMO, sec VMA intine and 6xHis tag'.

So, based strictly on this context, the answer is yes, at least one iGEM team has utilized histidine tags for protein purification in their project.

question: Have any iGEM teams explored the use of novel signal peptides to enhance protein secretion in their projects?
reference_answer: Although the provided context does not explicitly mention an iGEM team, it does describe a project that involves attaching a novel signal peptide (NSP4) to PETase to enhance its secretion, suggesting that the team working on this project may be an iGEM team or have a similar approach to an iGEM team.
qa_context: Novel signal peptide NSP4 that was reported in Soojin Han el al.(2017)s research paper was attached to PETase(28-290), and when predicted, it was estimated to have a higher probability of secretion than SPLamB-PETase(33-290) In order to confirm the predicted data, we induced PETase that has each signal peptides attached with light at 18 C for 24 hours.

qa_meta.Project_Title: Development of PET Degradation Device Using Transgenic Escherichia Coli
qa_meta.Abstract: In the past 65 years (1950 to 2015) only 7% of the 83 billion tons of plastic have been recycled, and 50% has been dumped into the environment. The effort of reducing plastic in the environment is being made by various fields, however due to the high cost of plastic treatment and its harmful side products a breakthrough is yet to be made. In this project we have established an improved PET degradation system. First, we utilized point mutations with enhanced PET degradation, and implemented a light inducible promoter to regulate the expression of PET-degrading enzymes more effectively. To increase the efficiency of the enzyme expression, we determined the best combination of some constitutive promoters and RBS. Not only that, we used a new signal peptideto increase the amount of secreted enzymes. From these results, we constructed a circulating incubator in which PET is degraded by transgenic E.coli.

answer: Yes, the SIS Korea team has explored the use of a novel signal peptide (NSP4) to enhance protein secretion in their project, 'Development of PET Degradation Device Using Transgenic Escherichia Coli'

question: Have any iGEM teams developed projects or proposed solutions to address concerns about vaccine authenticity or halal certification?
reference_answer: No information is provided in the given context about specific iGEM teams working on this topic.
qa_context: Parents were still taken aback after fake vaccine scandal in 2016. Fake vaccines ranges from boosters of hepatitis B, diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough. Indonesia is a nation home to largest Muslim population in the world. There have been rumours circulating the public regarding non-halal vaccines.

qa_meta.Project_Title: How I Met Diphto
qa_meta.Abstract: Diphtheria, a lethal disease caused by the toxigenic strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, afflicted Indonesia in /10 mortality rates upon 593 national cases. Complicated diagnostic method and ambiguous symptoms were the main obstacles in giving the optimal treatment, according to physicians. Therefore, a fast and convenient novel approach to enhance diagnostic precision is needed to mitigate diphtheria immediately. In regards, our team focuses on developing the diagnostic tool using K-12 chimeric bacteria and green fluorescent protein (GFP) to enable a rapid detection of Diphteria toxin upon binding. This novel technology is claimed to be fast, available, and easy-to-usewhich sets stepping stones regarding to the establishment of primary diagnostic tool for Diphtheria toxin worldwide. In addition, we aim to prevent future outbreaks using public education to enhance awareness regarding anti-hoax movements and introduce daily probiotic consumption to encounter low usages of probiotic in Indonesia

answer: No information about iGEM teams developing projects or proposals addressing vaccine authenticity or halal certification is present in the provided context.

qdrant_context.Abstract: In iGEM 2017, our team successfully designed a DNA three dimensional nano-structure to detect the presence and concentration of H3N2 influenza mRNA biomarker. To further prove the ability of the DNA nano-structure, this year we used four DNA strands to form a DNA nano-structure to detect the presence and the concentration of Lactobacillus instead of just a gene fragment of a bacterium. We successfully designed nano- triangular bipyramid applicable to the bacterium using Tiamat. We then successfully detect the presence and concentration of bacteria by measuring its peroxidase activity.
qdrant_context.Project_Title: NANO-TECHtrahedron: Using nano-tetrahedron to check for the probiotic concentration from food sample

Professor Kwan from The Chinese University of Hong Kong suggested that it could be feasible to design such a device. He also instructed us to use various online platforms, such as BLAST, to find out the appropriate sequence of the bacteria as our target sequence.

qa_meta.Project_Title: Eco-life, better life
qa_meta.Abstract: It is the Tunghai team`s first year to compete in the iGEM competition. Our team consists of 15 students working together in multidisciplinary teams to achieve our goal. Our members come from different backgrounds, with majors such as chemistry, chemical engineering, biology. However, we have something in common- we all are interested in synthetic biology and admire the concept of iGEM. At first, we were frustrated because of all of the details that need to be carefully accounted for, but after a lot of dedication, we observed that people are suffering HAI(Hospital Acquired Infection) these days. It can`t be denied how crucial the whole environment is to this human being. Therefore, we invented a new product and named it `EcoLife`, with its primary purpose being a air purifier. With this product, we are looking to provide a instrument alternative for those who pursue a healthy life.

qdrant_context.Abstract: In iGEM 2017, our team successfully designed a DNA three dimensional nano-structure to detect the presence and concentration of H3N2 influenza mRNA biomarker. To further prove the ability of the DNA nano-structure, this year we used four DNA strands to form a DNA nano-structure to detect the presence and the concentration of Lactobacillus instead of just a gene fragment of a bacterium. We successfully designed nano- triangular bipyramid applicable to the bacterium using Tiamat. We then successfully detect the presence and concentration of bacteria by measuring its peroxidase activity.

question: Have any iGEM teams developed or utilized novel methods for DNA visualization or agarose gel electrophoresis in their projects?
reference_answer: The provided context does not mention any specific iGEM team or project, but it does describe a general protocol for agarose gel electrophoresis, suggesting that teams may have used this or similar methods in their projects.
qa_context: Dissolve 1g in 100 mL TAE 1X for 1% agarose and heat the mixture in microwave for 1-3 minutes or until the mixture looked clear 2.Pour agar mixture in the gel cast and place a well comb.Wait until the gel solidify 3.Place gel in electrophoresis chamber filled with 1X TAE buffer 4.Insert mixture of DNA ladder and loading dye, and insert all samples (add loading dye if the sample doesnt include one) 5.Run electrophoreis at 70V, for about 30-40 minutes 6.Visualize the DNA by staining the gel with EtBr solution, and destain it before observation.

qa_meta.Project_Title: shrimpal.id: Early Detection Tool for White Feces Disease in White Shrimp Ponds
qa_meta.Abstract: Vibrio parahaemolyticus, an emerging pathogen of white shrimp that cause White Feces Disease (WFD), still poses major threat in white shrimp industry. Unfortunately, Vibrio parahaemolyticus is hard to detect; shrimp farmers tries to estimate its existence through physicochemical and traditional parameterswhich does not always give accurate prediction. We design Escherichia coli that could detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in shrimp pond water and estimates its quantity. We try to express the signaling proteins of Vibrio parahaemolyticus in Escherichia coli: LuxN, LuxO, and LuxU and integrate them with dCas9 system that regulates GFP expression. It is expected that when the Vibrio parahaemolyticus level is high, it would produce enough autoinducer molecules to be detected by LuxN and induces the cascade of the system until GFP is expressed. This system would allow shrimp farmers to detect Vibrio parahaemolyticus in their ponds earlier and easier, hence they could do preventive measures to stop WFD.

answer: According to the provided context, there is no information about any other iGEM teams or their methods. The provided context only discusses the project of ITB Indonesia team and their methods for DNA visualization and agarose gel electrophoresis.
